description: A continuing exploration of architectural design. Content and technique in representation and construction are explored through various studio design exercises.
name: ARCHITECTURE & LANDSCAPE DESIGN II

values.comments:
This course is an introduction to the fundamentals of design three-dimensional objects of use. Concepts and techniques of description, projection, and fabrication will be explored through a series of workshop exercises using parametric solid modeling, computer-aided design software, rapid prototyping (3D printing), and laser cutting technology. The course is intended to provide a background in three- dimensional design fundamentals for students in engineering, business, and fine arts.

This course seriously displeased students. One student wrote, “Excruciating, frustrating, miserable, and cruel are 4 adjectives that barely begin to describe this course.” In particular, the large group project required for the class stressed some students to an extreme. They thought that the amount of coordination it required between students as well as time in the computer lab made the project very difficult. In addition, many students commented that they were often given contrary expectations about assignments which caused a great deal of confusion.

Students agreed that Professor Wesley was, in principle, willing to help students and acting in their best interest. He “offered many great insights and was very helpful in my design growth” one student said. “I really appreciate [his] commitment to providing guidance for anyone who seeks it, and [his] genuine interest in our success.” However, many students thought that Professor Wesley and the co-teaching professor, Professor Erdy, “were not on the same page much of the time.”

This course is listed as being worth two credits. However, most students said that the professors far overshot their target workload to be attributed for these credits. “The amount of work hours required by the professors (and the fact that we are often kept an hour or two past the four hour sessions because professors have trouble keeping track of time) is unacceptable and disproportionate compared to all other undergraduate majors at Penn,” one student said. In addition, the fact that the projects were often conducted in groups and required specialized computer software made the course challenging to manage with other classes and commitments.
